div.p:
The Lord of the castle of is old, and greyheaded
Fourscore years have passflitted over him, silently and unawares and the dream of
life is nigh to its awaking, and his ear is dull, and his
eye is dim, and his heart is weary.

The old man reclines on a couch in the hall of his
ancestors, and beside an open casement, and the balmy
air that dr floats over the deep blue waters of the broad
sea passes softly over his gleaming hair; and his weary
eye rests on the brightness of an exceeding lovely landscape
for the olive and the orange and the myrtle are green
by the shore of the still waters, and the city gleams whitely
beneath the glance of the sun as he rides through the
cloudless azure of the su heaven, and the purple mountains
clasp the ocean in their arms, and fade away into the horizon
in long lines of misty blue.

Alas, the spring time of nature is a mockery to the
winter of old age, and the old man turns away in sadness
He is begins by His vassals are waiting around him to
do him pleasure, the minstrel is there with his harp. the
maiden with her song, but no music is so sweet to
the old mans ear as the voice of his daughter Giulietta.

Giulietta, when a babe, was a thing of smiles and loveliness
like a happy thought dancing over the mind’
Giulietta, when a child, was like the orange blossom in
the groves of Friuli, and gladness floated around her like the
fragrance of the flower. Giulietta in her youth is the
fairest maiden of Italy, she glanced among the myrtle
bowers like the wayward winged zephyr, the evening star when
it trembles over rises gleaming out of the sea into
the darkness of the glorious night of Italy is not so
bright as the lig beam that flashes from her large
eye through the night of her lovely eye lashes.
Like music to the sadness of the soul, so was Giulietta
to the old age of her Father, as she passed before him
a light came into the coldness of his eye, and his ear
when it was dead to other sound, awoke to the murmur
of her gentle voice (Giuliettas mind was love. all love
continual love to each and every thing, the birds
knew Giulietta, (the nightingale sang at her chamber window
his song to the stars,) and (as she walked among the
flowers they fluttered beside her. and stooped their glossy necks
to the land) nay, the flowers seemed to know Giulietta
and to be gladdened into brighteness as she past, and Giulietta
loved them all.) To her father,— as an angel watches over the last days of a saint upon the earth, when the tumult
of the battle of his life is oer, and sheds peace around his hours
and bids his days pass sweetly and holily, so Giulietta watched
over the old man like an influence of good and was the sun of his
thoughts, and the light of his rejoicing.

Giulietta had a brother;Garciowas feared by many
and loved by few was a man of a dark countenance
and the shadows of his evil passions passed over it like clouds
over the luridness of the stormy heaven, and his look withered
those upon whom it fell, and his wrath, once excited raged
like a pestilence, and would not be appeased, he was feared by
all, hated by many, loved by few, but his arm was restless in the
battle, and his faire? was bright among the proud and
of the warriors of Italy.

But one of the maidens of Giulietta, when she heard
the peasant's tale, went and sought for Giuulietta in her

ber, and she was not there, and
and she descended by the secret staircase,
and she saw footsteps in the dew on the grassy ground.
Then she returned weeping, ‐ and she came to the the old man he's
father of Giulietta‐and told him that Leoni the bandit
had carried heraway Giulietta.
And the old man was weak, and very feeble‐ and he could not grieve
and he bowed his head gently upon his
breast and died.
And the spirit went forth with a complaining, and passed
moaning on the night wind in search of those whom it loved‐
And it wentfled forth like a wrath of sea
mist along the shore and came and looked
over the head of Giulietta, as she fled
with Leoni, and as the spirit came near
with her she rememembered her father and how
he had said that the sea would not rise to him
And she stopped in great misery, exclaiming‐
oh my father, my father surely I have murdered thee
my father‐Then she heard through her weeping the
noise of a soft sigh beside her‐ and she startled
and looked round‐it was with‐like the voice of
the wind among the birdslaurel leaves,
neither like the mummers of the little waves upon the shore
And she said to Leoni
“Heardest thou nothing?” Giulietta said to Leoni.
“Nothing , Giulietta,” he replied. "Nay, now
that I listen, methinks I hear a sound, far away, like
the tramp of steeds along the sand.” And Giulietta
listened, and she was filled with great fear.
“Ohl fly, Leoni!” she said, “it is Garcio! fiy,
and leave me here!”
